description: Extracts analytical frameworks, theoretical models, and typologies developed or used in a collection. Maps framework components, relationships, and applications. Enhanced with genealogy-oriented dimensions: vocabulary mapping, methodological signature profiling, metaphor tracking, and framing analysis — enabling downstream genealogical tracing through an author's prior works.
researcher_question: What analytical frameworks structure thinking in this collection?

frameworks.name: string
frameworks.framework_type: theoretical_model | typology | taxonomy | causal_model | analytical_lens | process_model | matrix

relationships.relationship_type: causes | correlates | contains | precedes | contrasts | enables

vocabulary.term: string - key term or phrase used within this framework
vocabulary.definition_given: string - how the author defines or deploys this term (may be implicit)
vocabulary.is_coined: boolean - whether this term appears to be the author's own coinage or distinctive usage
likely_precursor_terms: string - terms that might have been used for the same concept in earlier work, even if different words

frameworks.methodological_signature: string - how does the author ARGUE for this framework? What evidence type, logical structure, or analytical move supports it?
metaphors: string - metaphors or analogies used to convey or justify this framework

framing.acknowledges_prior_work: string | null - does the author reference their own or others' earlier work on this framework?
framing.what_is_suppressed: string | null - what qualifications, alternatives, or complications does the framing suppress?

domain_crossings.source_domain: string - where this concept or method originates
domain_crossings.what_is_imported: string - what specific concept, method, or structural analogy is brought from the source domain
domain_crossings.adaptation: string - how it's been adapted for the current argument

frameworks.genealogical_hints: string | null - any signals that this framework has a history: self-references, evolved terminology, claims that feel 'settled' without adequate justification in this text alone

coined_terms: string - terms that appear to be the author's own creation or distinctive usage

repurposed_terms.standard_meaning: string - how this term is normally used in the field
repurposed_terms.author_meaning: string - how the author uses it differently

key_oppositions.what_the_opposition_structures: string - what analytical work this opposition does in the argument

primary_evidence_types: string - what kinds of evidence the author relies on (historical narrative, economic data, theoretical derivation, analogy, thought experiment, case study)
methodological_profile.argumentative_structure: string - how does the author characteristically build arguments?
recurring_analytical_moves: string - moves the author makes repeatedly (e.g., 'reframes X as Y', 'appeals to structural necessity', 'derives from historical narrative')
methodological_profile.what_counts_as_evidence: string - what does the author treat as sufficient evidence for a claim? Reveals epistemological commitments

metaphor_inventory.source_domain: string - where the metaphor draws from
metaphor_inventory.analytical_weight: heavy | moderate | decorative - how much argumentative work this metaphor does
frameworks_using_it: framework_id - which frameworks rely on this metaphor
metaphor_inventory.role_in_argument: string - what function this metaphor serves (explanation, persuasion, structure, etc.)

framing_landscape.problem_framing: string - how the central problem or question is framed
foregrounded_aspects: string - what the framing emphasizes or centers
backgrounded_aspects: string - what the framing de-emphasizes, omits, or renders invisible

claimed_novelty: string - what the author explicitly claims is new or original
claimed_continuity: string - what the author claims continues from prior work
intellectual_opponents: string - who or what the author positions themselves against
intellectual_allies: string - whose frameworks or positions the author builds on

meta.vocabulary_richness: number - total coined + repurposed terms identified

extraction.core_question: What analytical frameworks structure thinking in this collection?
extraction_steps: IDENTIFICATION: Identify all analytical frameworks, theoretical models, and typologies in the text.
COMPONENTS: For each framework, map its components and their roles.
RELATIONSHIPS: Map relationships between framework components.
APPLICATION: Document how each framework is applied and with what success.
LIMITATIONS: Note stated or implied limitations of each framework.

VOCABULARY EXTRACTION: For each framework, extract the key terms it introduces or relies on. Note which terms appear to be coined by the author, which are standard terms used non-standardly, and what precursor terms might exist in earlier work. Build the overall vocabulary_map: coined terms, repurposed terms, and key oppositions that structure the argument.

METHODOLOGICAL SIGNATURE PROFILING: Characterize HOW the author argues for each framework. What evidence types support it? What analytical moves recur? Build the overall methodological_profile: primary evidence types, argumentative structure, recurring analytical moves, and what counts as evidence. These signatures persist across an author's career and are reliable markers for genealogical tracing.

METAPHOR TRACKING: Identify metaphors and analogies used within each framework and across the text. Assess how much argumentative weight each metaphor carries (heavy = does real analytical work; decorative = merely illustrative). Metaphors are genealogy gold — they migrate across works, sometimes gaining, sometimes losing analytical power.

FRAMING ANALYSIS: For each framework, assess how it is framed: as novel, established, building on prior work, contested, or self-evident? How confident is the author (tentative, qualified, definitive, axiomatic)? Does the author acknowledge prior work? What does the framing suppress? Build the overall framing_landscape: how the central problem is framed, what is foregrounded vs. backgrounded, and how the author positions themselves relative to allies and opponents.
DOMAIN CROSSINGS: For each framework, identify where concepts, methods, or structural analogies are imported from other fields. Each crossing is a potential genealogical thread.

GENEALOGICAL HINTS: Flag any signals that a framework has a history in the author's prior work: self-references, evolved terminology, claims that feel 'settled' without adequate justification in this text alone, or structural similarities to arguments the author is known for.

key_fields.vocabulary: Key terms with their specific usage — downstream passes search for these in prior works
key_fields.methodological_signature: How the author argues for this framework — downstream passes match these patterns
key_fields.framing: How the framework is presented — downstream passes check whether earlier framings match

extraction.special_instructions: When used for genealogical analysis: you are not just extracting frameworks — you are building a GENEALOGICAL PROFILE. Every dimension you extract (vocabulary, methods, metaphors, framing, domains) becomes a search target for downstream passes that will scan prior works for resonance, evolution, and tactical moves. Be thorough but selective — focus on frameworks substantial enough to have a genealogy. Pay special attention to: (1) terms that feel established but aren't justified here — they may rely on authority from prior work; (2) methodological moves that feel habitual — they likely trace back years; (3) metaphors doing heavy analytical lifting — they probably evolved from simpler forms. If Runtime Context is provided, adapt your analysis accordingly.

consolidation_rules: CONSOLIDATE FRAMEWORKS: Merge same frameworks across articles
MAP FRAMEWORK RELATIONSHIPS: - Which frameworks compete?
TRACK APPLICATIONS: - How are frameworks actually used?
IDENTIFY EMERGENT FRAMEWORKS: - Are new frameworks being proposed?
ASSESS LANDSCAPE: - What framework types dominate?
MERGE VOCABULARY: Consolidate vocabulary maps across documents — track which terms appear consistently vs. in isolated contexts
MERGE METHODOLOGICAL PROFILES: Identify which analytical moves persist across documents vs. which are context-specific
TRACK METAPHOR EVOLUTION: If the same metaphor appears across documents, note how its usage or weight changes
